lines.text: Is, uh, is, uh, you folks, uh...?
Could you be apt to telling me if there's a certain Mr. Millford, the horse breeder, anywhere about?
I don't rightly know what you's saying, missy. I'm here to pick up some folks that's going out to Mr. Millford's farm. A couple of foreigners.
What language is this strange person talking, Maggie?
I'm not sure.
Don't y'all speak the English language?
Yes, we do. Now, you listen carefully. This is Mr. Shawn O'Hara. I'm his niece. We've come all the way from Ireland. Mr. Millford's expecting us. Mr. Millford!
Yes'm. Yes'm. You is which I'm looking for. I'm Mr. Millford's boy.
His boy, you say?
Yes, sir. Murphy's the name, sir.
Murphy - Did he say Murphy?
I think he did, Uncle Shawn. Did you say Murphy?
Yes, missy. Murphy. They calls me Walkin' Murphy.
Walkin' Murphy?
Yes'm. Most of us Murphys down here just sit. I walk.
Well, that's fine.
Murphy! Now what part of Ireland are you from?
I don't rightly know, sir. Us Murphys down here only got a casual acquaintance with the Irish.
Come on, Murphy. Take us to Mr. Millford.
I almost forgot what Mr. Millford said.
[clears his throat]
Welcome to Kentucky, the Bluegrass state.
Thanks, Murphy. Start walking.
Yes'm.
Paris, Murphy, Bluegrass...
It's a strange, new world, Uncle Shawn.
I hear you're a magician, Shawn. You can look at a yearling and tell like that whether he'll turn out champion or cow.
lines.character: George Carson, Head Trainer at Milford Farms

lines.text: You exaggerate my abilities, George, but...
But that's exactly why you're here, Shawn.
Oh, brother! Why, we can't even tell when they're two-year-olds. Even after we've tested them plenty against each other we sometimes let a future winner go to the sales.
lines.character: George Carson, Head Trainer at Milford Farms

lines.text: Perhaps you've let too many winners get away, Mr. Carson.
Now, Maggie, naturally George is doubtful.
In all the years Uncle Shawn trained for Lord and Lady Maitland in Ireland, devil a colt that turned the trick was sold by them.
All right, Miss Margaret. Let me in on the secret, will you?
lines.character: George Carson, Head Trainer at Milford Farms

lines.text: Of course. 'Tis simple. When it comes to a thoroughbred horse, Uncle Shawn is fey.
Fey? What's that?
lines.character: George Carson, Head Trainer at Milford Farms

lines.text: elves, gnomes, fairies.
So we're going to have the fairies pick our horses for us. Well, I give up. Boss, you can have my resignation whenever you want it.
lines.character: George Carson, Head Trainer at Milford Farms

lines.text: Of course not. Don't fly off the handle. You and Shawn will make a great team.
You've a perfect right to know why I came to America. I'm through training jumping horses for the rest of me days. No doubt you remember the last grand national at Aintree?
Oh, sure. I remember.
lines.character: George Carson, Head Trainer at Milford Farms

lines.text: I saddled the favorite, Blackwatch. And the jockey was Danny, Margaret's brother. He was a great jockey and a great lad. Blackwatch was the best horse, and Danny the best jockey that day. We were the favorite. We had it won handily. He was running easily. It was just as though Danny were taking that grand, strong horse for a gallop. Sure there were jumps, and Blackwatch flew over them. Then came the last jump. Who knows what happened? Not I. Not anyone. They failed to clear it, and Blackwatch was down with Danny under him. Both boy and horse were done for when I got there. For 30 years I've been training jumpers in the so-called sport of kings. But that day at Aintree it came to me that when you kill a lovely lad and break the back of a fine horse the devil's in it, and not kings. A large part of me heart is in Danny's grave. And as for Margaret, I only hope the time will come when the blackness of that day will be lifted from her soul.
You judge the next two or three, George. Shawn and I won't open our heads.
I'll not so much as whisper. I give you me word.
Come on with him.
[stable hand brings up Seabiscuit]
And that was bred here? What is it?
Seabiscuit by Hard Tack out of Swing On.
lines.character: George Carson, Head Trainer at Milford Farms

lines.text: He's always been kind of runty.
Yeah. Runty's right. Look at those knees. Big enough for a three-year-old. Well, George, deciding about this one won't strain you.
Get him to the shipping paddock, quick.
lines.character: George Carson, Head Trainer at Milford Farms

lines.text: One minute. Mr. Millford, I gave you me word, and you can call me what you like, but I'm going to have me say. I'm begging you, I'm praying you, don't let this little man go.
Well, can you beat that? Boss, I've stood for a lot here this morning, but if you keep this runty, big-kneed thing on the say of this Irish expert, I'm getting off the place.
lines.character: George Carson, Head Trainer at Milford Farms

lines.text: give this colt a chance to show you what he can do.
Nobody's going to leave over one yearling. Shawn, I promised George, and I'm keeping my word. Shipping paddock.
The day will come, sir, when you'll hold your head higher and breathe deep to be called his owner.
You die hard, don't you, Shawn.
I doubt if it's hard enough.
You know, you've got an accent just like old Shawn. On you I like it.
My, you're a fast starter.
That's my reputation. Then you did know all along who I was.
I found out.
Interested?
I should have known you were a jockey.
Oh, that's all right. I can't expect you to know everything before we've even got started.
Jockey's have sort of a special something about them that's easy to tell.
Uh, the bandy legs?
'Tis more a secret thing of the spirit, I'm thinking.
Say, what's your name?
Margaret O'Hara.
Margaret. I'll tell you what, Margaret. I'll win my first race this year for you, if you promise to be there with maybe a two-spot on his nose.
No. Never.
Why not?
It would be bringing back a black memory to torment me.
Well, now who's talking crazy? Look, Margaret, I've got to work a couple more horses. Where can I see you again soon?
No place at all.
No place at all? Am I that hard on the eyes?
You're not hard on the eyes at all, Ted, but you're a jockey. Goodbye.
Say, I think your niece is swell.
Well, you can't start an argument with me that way, me boy.
I just wanted to know if it'd be okay by you if I dated her.
And if it shouldn't be okay by me, I'm thinking you'd start an argument.

Well, I thought maybe you had it in for jocks, too. Darned if I don't think I'd stand a better chance with her if I were a stable boy. She's a mystery, that Margaret is. You know, Mr. O'Hara, maybe you could put in a good word for me.

Well, now, being the kind of man you are, Ted, I've an idea you can solve that mystery without my help. However, I might be willing to put in a word here and there if you do me a bit of a favor in return.
Anything you say.
I'll not say much. Just buy that colt there, Seabiscuit.
Me, buy that little squirt? What for?
I like him.
But he hasn't got a chance. George doesn't think so either, or he wouldn't be shipping him.
I think you're both mistaken.
Well, if you're so sure, why don't you buy him yourself?
No, no. So long as I train for other people, I'll never race one of me own. I might be tempted to give him special consideration.
I feel the same way myself.
I agree with you, Margaret, he should get to a warmer climate.
Where should I be taking him for a warmer climate?
You'll go with him?
Oh, indeed'n I will, sir.
Well, what about your nursing?
I'll be nurse to him and him alone until he's well.
Well, then. I think we'd better make it California. Charlie Howard bought a stock farm out there. He could use a man like Shawn.
We really got to go east and do some buying. I got my eye on one or two I think we can get.
Good, we'd better start right away.
Wait a minute, now, I don't know whether I trust you two boys to go shopping or not.
Shawn will see that no one puts anything over on me. Have you any particular favorites?
No, not offhand. Oh, yes, come to think of it, now. I do know of one. And he shouldn't cost you too much, either. Sir, it would be a pleasure to go east to the sales with you. Indeed it will, sir!
Did you buy anything?
No, but I'm going to buy one now, if you'll sell. I saw a three-year-old of yours running in a selling race this afternoon, smallish sort of colt with big knees, Seabiscuit.
Seabiscuit? Why do you want him?
Well, you can't shoot for the stakes all the time. I gotta have some horses for cheap races. He was entered for 6000. Will you take 8000 for him?
Well, I think so. How about it, George?
The string's pretty large, boss. We've got a lot like him.
lines.character: George Carson, Head Trainer at Milford Farms

lines.text: It's a deal, Charlie.
Good. We'll get him tomorrow. By the way, Tom, I hired Shawn O'Hara on the strength of your letter.
[Mr. Milford and George look at each other and laugh]
What's the joke?
Oh, nothing. Only George and I know now why you want the Biscuit. And listen, Charlie, when you get him back to California, don't let Shawn stable him in the living room!
Listen, Ted, you just finished third on a colt that could have won.
Oh, is that so? The bad ride beat him, huh?

No. His disposition beat him. He's too friendly, too sociable for his own good. Now, I've been working on an idea. I cut two holes in his blinkers, and here's what you've got to do. The next time you start with him, take him to the front if you can. When you can see the head of a horse closing in on you out of the corner of your eye, hit the Biscuit with all the power that's in you, three times, no more. After that, hand ride him to the wire. Is that clear now?
Sure, that's easy.
And get this. Do it every time you start, three terrible, hard cuts.
Okay, then what?

He'll soon learn it's not play, and it won't be long till you notice him cocking an ear back to listen at what's coming up behind. After that, you'll not need the whip. He'll get up and go to get away from it when he gets a peek at the closing horse through the holes in his blinkers.
Well, it won't hurt to try. I'll ride him just that way.
I think it'll work.
Margaret's in Los Angeles, isn't she?
Yes, she's a full-fledged nurse now.
You know, I can't get her out of my mind.
Maybe you don't want to. Are you in love with her, Ted?
You're darn tooting.
I'm tooting she's in love with you, too.
So, that ought to make it a sure thing, but it doesn't.
You'll have to bear with her, Ted. She's running away from Danny's memory.
But she's not running away from it, Shawn. It's right with her all the time. I wonder if she saw me ride a winner if maybe that would fix things. What do you think?
That's an idea. I'll have her at the track for the San Carlos.
Oh, that'll be great.
But I'll tell you all the news later. Get in some other clothes. You're going to Santa Anita with me.
Well, Seabiscuit isn't running today, is he?
No, he's not, but you'll see something with two legs who's in a fair way to become a champion himself. Need I tell you his name?
No, you needn't. I can't go. I'm on duty.
You love Ted, don't you?
Please, Uncle Shawn. This isn't the time or the place. I told you, I'm on duty.

I'm thinking of your duty to yourself. You're neglecting it shamefully. You'll never be happy sticking your head out of sight like a bloomin' ostrich. Hold it up proud, me girl, and face the truth. Now, hurry, you're free for the afternoon.
Who said so?
The superintendant. I just talked with her.
You didn't tell her we were going to the races?
I told her you were my niece, that I was from Ireland, and that I'd be in Los Angeles for just this afternoon.
Why you lying old devil.
Oh, you do me a great wrong, Maggie. There's not a word of a lie in it. You're me niece right enough, and surely to goodness I'm from Ireland, and I'm driving back to the ranch this very night.
Are you sure it was the superintendant, Miss Newsome, you saw? I doubt her letting anyone off for any reason.
That's it, Newsome. A sour, old witch with a voice like a foghorn, and an eye like a tomcat.

[coming up behind them]
Did I hear my name?

Me dear, lady, you did indeed. I was just talking about a Miss Newsome of County Kerry. I was thinking how strange it was that you, so kind, so generous, so understanding, should have the same name as that old harridan. Get into your street clothes quickly, child. There's a service at All Saints at two o'clock.
Get down, Tom. Lead him around once. That's bad.
What's the matter?
What is it?
The way he was using his right foreleg.
His leg? I didn't notice it.
I hope it's not what I'm thinking it is.
What is it, Shawn?
Tom, get the vet.
Yes, sir.
I can't rightly tell, but I don't like the feel of the leg at all.
But Shawn, he wasn't limping badly.
He was trying not to, bless his heart, but I doubt very much if he'll be able to run in the Santa Anita.
Oh, no.
That's terrible news.
A good soldier, home from the wars.
So many, many battles, poor darling.
No Santa Anita for us, fellow.
Don't say that yet, Ted.
What else would I say?
I don't know. What about it, Shawn?
The stud is the place for him, sir.
He can't be brought back?
I don't think so.
But Charlie, he's earned a rest.
You brought back Golden Girl, remember?
A young thing that ran half a dozen races with a feather on her back. He's run near 100, 30 of them in record time with high weight on him.
Then there's no chance?
A faint one, if any.
Faint or not, we'll take it. Not even you can talk me off the Biscuit, Shawn.
As you say, sir.
Well, what's the program?
Well, give up everything else and devote ourselves to nursing him alone.
All right, that's it. Ted, you stay and help us. We'll bring you back, too.
Thank you, sir. I'll stay.
You'll be right in your element here, Maggie. We're all nurses now.
Nurses?
The patient is one little horse, Seabiscuit. We're getting ready to try for the Santa Anita again.
But the paper said he was finished.
Yes, and I'd have sworn it, too, but now I know that so long as he can draw breath, you can't finish him. Tomorrow Ted is working him against the two best horses on the ranch.
Ted? Is he here?
As if you didn't know.
I've forgotten all about him. How is he?
Coming along as fine as Seabiscuit. In the Santa Anita, you'll see Ted up on him.
I won't see him.
You still love the lad, Margaret.
I tell you, he's out of my mind completely.
But not out of your heart.
Sure and I can't help myself. Ah, the devil take Ted Knowles.
Margaret, your happiness is more important than the big race. Would it lift the cloud off your eyes if I tried to talk Ted out of riding?
I'd be the happiest girl in the world. Uncle Shawn, you're a darling.
Oh, hold on now. It's not an accomplishment at yet.
You won't have any trouble getting someone just as good as Ted to ride the Seabiscuit.
Well, I've asked George Woolf to stand by in case Ted doesn't come around soon enough. Jockey for jockey there's little to choose between them.
Well then, things are going to work out right for everyone, aren't they?
'Tis to be hoped for, Maggie darling.
Aren't you going to have some of your chocolate cake? Wong makes it grand.
No, I can't touch it. But, I could have some if... Margaret, listen to me. You wouldn't marry Ted Knowles the jockey. Would you marry Ted Knowles your Uncle Shawn's assistant?
Ted, do you really think he meant you?
Yes, that scheming, conniving old faker. He's as sound as he ever was. You know what I think? You put him up to it.
Oh, no, Ted. It was his idea entirely.
You O'Haras. I think maybe I'm marrying a -
[Margaret kisses him]
An O'Hara will do anything to get what he wants. At least, that's the way it is with this O'Hara.
[Ted kisses her]

[pulls out a wedding ring]
Here. Try this on.
Oh, Ted, darling. It's sparkling like my heart. And how did you happen to bring it along tonight? Could it be, now, that you've planned the whole thing with Uncle Shawn?
No. I bought it the day before I went to the hospital. I've been carrying it around just in case. The O'Haras have nothing on the Knowles when it comes to getting what they want.
Ted, darling, you're a wonderful boy to give up what you love best for me.
What I used to love best doesn't count anymore. You're my favorite across the board.
Ted, I've just had news of a startling nature. George Woolf has signed to ride Heel Fly for the Circle F.
No kidding?
We're in a pickle. And there's only one way out.
[looking pointedly at Ted]
That's a bad break. No, sir. Nothing doing. I'm going to be sitting up in the grand stand with my best girl by my side.
Ted. Just a minute. Now, see here, lad. You brought this about. You'd no right to tell George you were definitely riding the Biscuit.
Now, wait a minute...

Now, don't attempt to evade the situation. It rests squarely on your strong, young shoulders. Would you let Mr. Howard down? And through Mr. Howard me, your uncle-to-be? And through me, Margaret, the girl you love?
Look who's talking. Who got me to give up riding? Who talked about food until I was starving to death?
Aw, food is for pigs.
Who practically forced me to take the job of assistant trainer?
It was an old man talking to you, boy. An old man with the blood dried in his veins. You should never listen to such nonsense.
I don't know. No that I think about it, I kind of like the idea of sitting in the grandstand.
Oh, the saints preserve us! Did I ever think I'd see a young jock with the hot blood in him ready to swap a seat on a horse for one on the grandstand?
You can talk all you want. It won't do any good. I gave Margaret my promise.

Ah, yes, but was your heart in your promise? Do you really want to see some other jockey on the Biscuit in the handicap? Are you the sort of boy that any old fool like meself can talk out of the greatest thrill in the world, winning the Santa Anita? What's sitting in the grandstands compared to checking your horse at the starting gate? And the gate sprung, and you're off. You feel Seabiscuit running swift and sure...
Cut it out. You know I'd give my right eye to be up there.
You shouldn't have interrupted. I had the race all but won for you.
But I won't be winning it. When Margaret comes back she expects to find me a trainer. And that's just what I'm gonna be.

Ted, a word to the wise. The O'Hara women are not inclined to favor men they can dominate. I recall sadly the case of my great Aunt Sheila, rest her soul. A beauty if ever there was one, and every young man for miles around showed he's willing to be a slave. She went to the grave an old maid. She didn't want slaves. She wanted to be one. Now, Margaret is much like Sheila.
Well, I'll write to Margaret, and if she says...

No, no, no. Let me do the telling. When she sees you again, she'll melt in your arms, loving you the more because you're a headstrong young bucko with a will of your own. No, let me do the telling. She's and O'Hara, and the O'Hara's understand each other and stick to each other through thick and thin.
Okay, Shawn. You've got yourself a boy. Providing you square it with the future Mrs. Knowles.
Right. Now get in the hot box and sweat off that steak and chocolate layer cake. Quickly now, or do I have to take the whip to you!
Now, Maggie, hold your horses!
Don't ever mention horses to me again!
If you'll only listen, I'll explain. An emergency call. Woolf signed with another stable. Ted was obligated to save the situation.
Why Ted? There are jockeys to be had for the asking.
None of them who know the Biscuit as well as Ted. And Maggie, darling, I had the devil's own time convincing him. But I finally persuaded him that you would see things in the proper light.
Why should I see it in what you're pleased to call the "proper light"?

Because as promised, it would have led to the lad's ruination. He was losing respect for himself. And before long, he would have lost respect for you as well. Now, go to him and tell him that you're as happy as a lark that he's riding the Biscuit in the handicap.
I can't do that. You ought to understand. You know how I feel.
I understand this, Margaret, that you're lacking in courage.
That's not fair.

Margaret, you've been running and running away from your problem instead of turning around and facing it squarely. Ted's going to ride in the big race. And I want you to want him to ride. It's the only thing that'll cure you.
Since when did your great knowledge of horseflesh extend itself to women? You-you two-faced old meddler!
Margaret.
Was ever a woman so humiliated, to have her man stolen by a horse?
You don't really mean that it's over?
'Tis not tricks that I'm up to, Ted. I came to say goodbye and to wish the two of you, you and Seabiscuit, the best of luck.
But, I thought you'd be able to forgive me when you saw how it was.
Forgive you for allowing Uncle Shawn's evil, old tongue to sway you?
I'm not hiding behind your uncle.
The old conniver. Oh, aren't you now? I suppose he had nothing to do with it.

I would have done it anyway. Because I love you, I thought it was the right thing for me to quit riding. But it wasn't right because it made me quit a loser. And this much I do know about the O'Haras, you wouldn't want a man that was a loser. So, I'll quit a winner or not at all.
Is that all you have to say, Ted?
That's all Margaret. Except, I love you.
Well, there he is. Boy, would I like to take him to the post again.
Ted.

Don't worry. He spoils you for riding any other horse. And look, baby, I'm not a jockey anymore. When those boys are out there fighting for position with mud in their eyes, I'm sitting up in the stands...
I know. Nice and easy with my little old sweetheart beside me.
[first lines]

[voice over narration]
Here in Kentucky is the Blue Grass Country where champions are born. Black, beige and chestnut. Glorious creatures. Born to run and keep on running.

[about Seabiscuit]
He is small. A full hen below the rest.
Sure he's small in the body, but big in the heart.
What do they call him?
Seabiscuit. You'd be hearing the name someday.
There they go!
Romance.
[last lines]
Eight thousand dollars and you advised me.
lines.character: George Carson, Head Trainer at Milford Farms

lines.text: Haven't I heard enough about that in the last five years boss?
